timeline.bodyHTML:
Passing the dummy new Object() into the Await util is okay. But you don't need to return it.

Success can be == doesn't throw an exception.

I'd update this for every method that uses this pattern.

Suggested change
/**
* Forgets the current device synchronously.
* @param device Auth device to forget
* @return Dummy object - just indicates it completed successfully
* @throws AuthException exception
*/
public Object forgetDevice(@NonNull AuthDevice device) throws AuthException {
return Await.<Object, AuthException>result(AUTH_OPERATION_TIMEOUT_MS, (onResult, onError) ->
asyncDelegate.forgetDevice(device, () -> onResult.accept(new Object()), onError)
);
}
/**
* Forgets the current device.
* @param device Auth device to forget
* @throws AuthException On failure to forget the provided device
*/
public void forgetDevice(@NonNull AuthDevice device) throws AuthException {
Await.<Object, AuthException>result(AUTH_OPERATION_TIMEOUT_MS, (onResult, onError) ->
asyncDelegate.forgetDevice(device, () -> onResult.accept(new Object()), onError)
);
}
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: This is the pattern that I usually follow, but I was trying to match the other methods in this class.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.body: Naming: this should be `forgetCurrentDevice()`, to clearly distinguish it from `forgetDevice(AuthDevice specificDevice)`. I would not compromise the naming just to match iOS. We should ask the iOS team to update their name if they're not using this, too.
timeline.bodyText: Naming: this should be forgetCurrentDevice(), to clearly distinguish it from forgetDevice(AuthDevice specificDevice). I would not compromise the naming just to match iOS. We should ask the iOS team to update their name if they're not using this, too.
timeline.bodyHTML: Naming: this should be forgetCurrentDevice(), to clearly distinguish it from forgetDevice(AuthDevice specificDevice). I would not compromise the naming just to match iOS. We should ask the iOS team to update their name if they're not using this, too.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: They have it set up such that AuthDevice parameter is nullable, and if none is passed, the method exhibits above behavior. It was in my discretion to overload the method and make AuthDevice a @NonNull parameter to go along with Android specific pattern. I believe it is okay to rename this method as you suggest.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.body: Since we have a `forceDevice(AuthDevice specificDevice)`, I suggest that we call this `rememberCurrentDevice()`. (Same for Rx bindings, of course, as well.)
